III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth's behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition,
medical condition, psychiatric condition, and personal
history, including any history of trauma, and must be done
in a manner consistent with the youth's treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A and Youth B were not restrained appropriately on multiple
occasions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
The Chief Administrator, Administrator 2 and Supervisor 1
were interviewed together on 07/18/2025. They shared case
service plan materials for Youth A as well as security camera
footage of restraint incidents. The Chief Administrator reported
staff at the facility had taken extra measures to attempt to
understand how to work best with Youth A and avoid escalated
physical incidents, including having her separated from youth in
units and coming up with separate programming and daily
schedules to best fit her needs. She provided documentation that
documented a timeline of incidents and administrative actions for
Youth A since she had been placed about a month prior. The
Chief Administrator described frequent meetings between
administration, direct care staff and supervisors, therapeutic staff
and Youth A’s case management to best support her. She also
reported that steps towards the possible placement of Youth A in
psychiatric programs had occurred but was unsure if those
placements would be obtained or not.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/18/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She confirmed she had been
restrained by staff on a frequent basis since her placement back
at the facility in mid-June 2025. Youth A commented every time
she has been restrained, she felt like it was warranted because
she is “always acting up” and she intentionally tries to hurt other
youth and staff. Youth A believed staff members communicated
well prior to and during restraints, stating she knew when a
2

restraint was coming because staff would tell her. Youth A
reiterated there was not a time she had been restrained she felt
was unwarranted because she would commonly start fights with
other youth and staff.
Youth B was interviewed on 07/18/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled a specific instance
when he was restrained by Staff 2 and Staff 3. Youth B recalled
being upset and stating something about wanting to go down the
hallway and fight other youth. He could not remember if he tried
to walk in that direction or if he was standing still. He recalled
balling up his fists and stating something threatening to the staff
members. He recalled one of Staff 2 or Staff 3 stating “We are not
going to keep doing this all day.” Youth B could not remember
other details other than being very upset and he intended to get to
some other youth to fight, commenting he was not going to listen
to staff and did not care they wanted to prevent him from doing
so. They then told him that he was going to be escorted to a room
for time to cool off. Youth B was unsure if he resisted the restraint
or not but commented he went into the bedroom willingly. Youth B
commented he has seen other youth be restrained during
escalated incidents and had no concern about the need or
implementation for the physical interventions.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/14/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He confirmed that he had spent a
significant amount of time working with Youth A and had to
participate in restraints with her. He described the work the
program has put in with Youth A as “creative” and “agile.” Staff 1
commented Youth A had been removed from the units with other
youth recently and had been spending time alone in other units or
in close observation areas of the facility. Administration has
created different procedures in working with Youth A, such as
allowing her into hallway areas youth would not normally be
allowed in attempts to reduce the chance of physical
restraint. Staff 1 reported Youth A is quick to escalate and does
not often give cues that physical aggression could be occurring.
He believed that she had some cognitive limitations but was
unsure. Staff 1 described common scenarios that would result in
physical escalation from Youth A, which did not always result in a
restraint. Staff 1 reported Youth A would randomly tell staff she
could knock them over or jump over them, and before any verbal
de-escalation could occur, she would try to do so with full physical
force. Staff 1 believed that several restraints of Youth A occurred
purely for her own physical safety. There were other instances
when she had to be restrained to prevent further assault of youth
3

or staff, some of which resulted in hospitalizations. Youth A had
shown assaultive behaviors such as impulsively attacking youth
and staff, throwing water or bodily fluids at staff and picking up
chairs and tables to with which to hit staff. Staff 1 believed any
restraint of Youth A only began because of physical contact she
initiated. Many times, Youth A’s restraints would be able to end
quickly because she would assault staff, but then not resist the
restraint attempt. He noted the occasions she did resist restraints
were difficult because she was strong and determined.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 08/14/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He reported struggles
with learning how to best work with Youth A in the face of what he
described as unpredictable behavior. Supervisor 2 felt the last
week or two involved having some breakthroughs with Youth A
and understanding her better than prior. He believed her rapport
with him had increased as well. An example of this was she
agreed to participate in a psychological evaluation only if
Supervisor 2 were present, which is not normally within his job
responsibility but something he would do to help benefit Youth
A. Supervisor 2 commented it was important to learn better how
to work with and support Youth A because there was a chance
she could be in and out of the detention facility for the next few
years based on her age and living situation. Supervisor 2
described experiences participating in restraints with Youth A. He
described a recent restraint occurred when Youth A had assaulted
staff. When Supervisor 2 came to swap in, Youth A commented
she would stop resisting. Supervisor 2 described recent changes
in working with Youth A to attempt to reduce physical
incidents. Staff had been instructed to not attempt to stand in the
doorway that exited the vestibule near Youth A’s bedroom. This
allowed her access to a hallway where youth were not normally
allowed to access. Youth A would commonly go into this hallway
and there were struggles with her behavior in that space.
However, Supervisor 2 believed this was something that needed
to be worked through compared to staff not allowing her access,
which commonly resulted in Youth A escalating physically. Overall
Supervisor 2 believed restraints of Youth A were warranted
because of her assaultive and dangerous behavior and they were
able to be performed as successful as possible. He believed
Youth A resisted being restrained more often at the beginning of
her placement, but her resistance has lessened the longer she’s
been placed.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed on 08/14/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He commented Youth
4

A was one of the most difficult to understand youth he had ever
worked with at the facility. He stated this was because her
behavior was quick to escalate without cues that normally could
be seen with other youth as they escalated. Supervisor 3 believed
Youth A displayed verbal “baiting” behaviors towards certain staff,
specifically Caucasian staff members. He had concerns she
displayed racist behaviors. Supervisor 3 witnessed Youth A
“testing” staff by stating she was going to do something assaultive,
waiting for their response and then acting on what she had
stated. Supervisor 3 recalled an instance when he subbed in for
another staff when Youth A was in a standing team control
restraint and as soon as he did, she commented that she would
commit to safety and then she calmed down. Another instance
involved Youth A first escalating by taking a drink cup from a staff
member and then beginning to threaten staff near her. Supervisor
3 could not recall who this was. Supervisor 3 recalled staff
members backing away from Youth A and not reacting to the staff
member’s taken item. Youth A then charged at a female staff and
Supervisor 3 then felt a restraint attempt was unavoidable.
Supervisor 3 recalled attempting a standing restraint with the
assistance of Supervisor 2. He recalled Youth A allowing them to
escort her to a different area away from the targeted staff member
and as they did, she showed signs of relaxation by loosening her
fists and her body feeling less tense. Supervisor 3 decided the
restraint could be ended and recalled Youth A then ran past then
to physically attack staff after he and Supervisor 2 disengaged.
Youth A then had to be restrained again. Supervisor 3 described
this as a good example of Youth A’s unpredictable and explosive
behavior. He felt unsure of Youth A’s physical and verbal cues of
calm behavior because there were examples of this behavior
changing immediately. He also remarked it had been difficult to
attempt to remove staff members from situations that Youth A
appeared to be triggered by or was targeting. This was caused by
staffing challenges. Supervisor 3 explained that staffing was
limited because of who was available at work as well as the
amount of staff that had been assigned to different levels of care
and supervision specific to Youth A, reducing availability
elsewhere in the program. Supervisor 3 commented it had been
beneficial for him and other staff to debrief and review security
camera footage of physically escalated incidents with Youth A.
Supervisor 4 was interviewed on 08/14/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated working
with Youth A on a consistent basis and on several occasions, he
was the supervisor that made the decision a restraint attempt was
necessary with her. He believed that he and other staff members
5

had attempted to and been able to avoid restraints with Youth A
for as long as possible. In his opinion they had attempted to avoid
restraints of Youth A longer than would have been implemented
with other youth. Supervisor 4 recalled frequent types of verbal
escalation from Youth A in that she would be calm and without
context would state “Should I hit you?”, “I can’t decide who to
throw this chair at” or “I don’t lie you, I am going to smack you in
the face.” Before staff could attempt to respond or verbally de-
escalate Youth A, she would begin her physically assaultive
behavior. He recalled one specific instance when Youth A asked
what time it was, and when answered she stated, “In five minutes I
am going to hit you” and then attempted to do so as she stated
she would. He expressed concern that Youth A was large enough
and strong enough that physically assaultive behavior had and
could injure youth and staff and that there were times when other
youth displaying the same behavior could have restraints avoided
because they were not as unsafe. Supervisor 4 remarked Youth
A’s exclusion from units with other youth was necessary for hers
and their safety, but it also caused frequent tension and physical
escalation because she would attempt to run past staff and
assault them in the process. Supervisor 4 also recalled Youth A
frequently throwing items at staff, such as food, toilet water or
bodily fluids on occasion. Supervisor 4 believed Youth A was
frequently assessing youth and staff for whom she could attempt
to manipulate or scare with her behavior. He believed the facility
had done a good job in carefully assigning staff to work with Youth
A in response but knew options were limited at times due to
staffing and the needs of other youth. Supervisor 4 believed any
restraint attempts of Youth A had always been in response to her
initiating physical contact and that staff had gained skills in
avoiding this when she was only verbally escalated or
threatening. He believed any restraints of Youth A were required
for safety of all involved by the time they were decided upon. An
example of this was recent changes in work with Youth A where
staff were allowing her access to a hallway that normally youth
would not have been allowed access to and would be escorted
from. Supervisor 4 believed this change in procedure was
warranted to further attempt to avoid physical incidents with Youth
A. Supervisor 4 recalled participating in frequent conversations
among staff and administration on how to best work with Youth
A. He was not fully aware of her diagnoses or treatment plan but
stated a phrase he heard her utter once stuck in his head, “Hurt
people hurt people.”
Staff 2 was interviewed on 08/14/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He confirmed that he had worked
6

frequently with Youth A and had to participate in restraints with
her, as well as restraints with other youth at the facility. In his
work with Youth A, Staff 2 believed that her explosive behavior
was based on her attempts to assess which staff she could
manipulate or not. Staff 2 stated Youth A escalated physically
faster than any other youth with which he had worked. She often
did not display body language or verbal cues that would give staff
reason to see her escalation coming. He recalled an example of
an incident with Youth A where she was in the vestibule of the
smaller bedroom location where she had been staying. Youth A
picked up a small desk and stated “I am going to throw this desk
at you” to Staff 2. She then immediately did so. Staff 2 was able
to block the desk and did not get knocked down or injured. Before
he attempted to restrain Youth A he backed up to assess her
behavior next and in doing so Youth A sat down, and a restraint
was able to be avoided. Staff 2 also reported Youth A had
physically assaulted another staff member minutes before this
interview. He was present for this incident. He described her
behavior as unpredictable in that she was being walked down to
take a shower at a different part of the facility. Youth A was doing
so in a calm manner and was not being physically escorted. As
soon as Youth A entered the shower area and noticed a staff
member, she had previously assaulted and then immediately
attacked this staff member without any verbal or other physical
cues. Staff 2 commented the restraint of Youth A in this instance
was very quick once the staff member she attacked was able to
move away from the situation. He also stated that restraint
incidents with Youth A would commonly follow this pattern in that
she would have to be restrained to keep others safe from her and
then would show signs of quick de-escalation only to physically
escalate and attempt to assault staff as soon as the restraint had
to be ended. Staff 2 also discussed restraints of other youth at the
program, including Youth B. He recalled an instance when he had
to help perform a restraint and escort of Youth B with the
assistance of Staff 3. Youth B was in an area of the facility where
he was not supposed to be and was verbally escalating. Staff 2
recalled Youth A being focused on wanting to fight other youth
that were elsewhere in an accompanying room down the
hallway. He recalled Youth B stating, “I’m going to blow through
you and get to the day room.” Youth B was balling his fists and
making flinch movements at Staff 2. Staff 2 recalled Youth B
attempting to push through him and Staff 3. Staff 3 initiated the
restraint and Staff 2 assisted. They used a two man transport into
a nearby bedroom. Staff 2 recalled Youth B resisting some as this
occurred, attempting to grab the doorframe of the room as they
7

entered and grabbed a nearby chair. Staff 2 noted that was the
one and only time he participated in a restraint with Youth B.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 08/18/2025. Staff 3
confirmed having worked frequently with Youth A and had
participated in restraints with her. He felt that no matter how
accommodating circumstances were made for Youth A, she would
still escalate and attempt to assault staff. This included daily
instances of spitting, hitting and throwing items at staff. Staff 3 felt
that the facility had made good efforts to adjust programming and
staffing in response to the greater behavioral needs of Youth A.
He also remarked that working with her was more difficult than
most youth because she had no “cues” that staff could learn to
help avoid escalation. An example of this was a common
exchange with Youth A where she would state something to the
effect of “At 4:15 I am going to hit you” and she then would follow
through, in addition to the frequent instances where she would
attempt to assault staff without any warning. Staff 3 recalled
participating in restraints with Youth A and a common theme was
that she would initially fight back but then show signs of calming
down, allowing staff to disengage. Youth A would then
immediately attempt to fight staff, causing restraint incidents to
frequently start and stop and start again. Staff 3 was asked about
the 06/24/2025 incident where Youth B was restrained. He
recalled being called for assistance as Youth B was getting upset
in a hallway. As he approached Youth B was interacting with Staff
2. Staff 3 recalled Youth B stating something about wishing he
had hit Staff 2 prior to the interaction. Youth B was escalating
verbally and was stating that he wanted to move past staff to get
to a room at the end of the hallway where other youth were in
order to fight them. Staff 3 knew that the door to that room Youth
B referenced was unlocked, and he felt concern that Youth B
would follow through. Staff 3 recalled Youth B attempting to move
past Staff 2, so he and Staff 2 initiated a standing escort restraint.
Staff 3 recalled Youth B continuing to be verbally escalated as this
occurred, yelling threats and slurs. Youth B was escorted to a
nearby bedroom within the hallway. Staff 3 recalled Youth B
attempting to block entry to the room but then stopping.
Video reviewed:
• Security camera footage located in multiple locations
showing ten separate restraint attempts of Youth A was
provided and reviewed.
o On 06/25/2025 Youth A was seen sitting in the
vestibule area with two holding rooms. She stood up
and walked towards the exit of the vestibule
8

area. Supervisor 2 attempted to block her from
leaving the vestibule area. Youth A continued to
attempt to move past staff to exit the vestibule area
and Supervisor 2 initiated a restraint on his own,
rapidly moving Youth A to the open bedroom and
holding her over the bed. Youth A was standing with
Supervisor 2 holding both of her wrists behind her
with his left hand and holding her torso down on the
next with his right hand on her upper back. After
releasing Youth A, Supervisor 2 attempted to leave
the room with Youth A attempting to leave with
him. Supervisor 2 had to make several attempts to
move Youth A back from the doorway to
successfully close the door.
o On 07/01/2025 Youth A was seen sitting in the
corner of the vestibule area with several staff in the
room with her. As she was sitting and staff were
speaking with her, Supervisor 2 initiated a restraint
on his own by taking a piece of clothing out of Youth
A’s hands and attempting to lift her up. Youth A was
placed in a standing escort restraint and moved into
the open bedroom nearby. Youth A kicked her left
leg in a manner that caused staff to fall to the
ground. Youth A was assisted to kneel at the back
of the room so that staff could leave the room
without her escalating further.
o On 07/02/2025 Youth A was seen in a unit with no
other youth placed and several staff speaking with
her. She was standing in a corner of the open area
of the unit, near one exit door. Youth A was facing
away from the door as several staff interacted with
her. Youth A was then taken to the ground by staff
and while initially lying on her stomach she was
immediately transitioned to a supine floor restraint.
• Security camera footage located in a unit hallway dated
06/24/2025 was provided and reviewed. In this footage
Youth B could be seen standing with Staff 2 and Staff
3. Youth B took a few slow steps down the hallway and
Staff 3 initiated a restraint by taking hold of Youth B’s left
arm. Staff 2 followed suit and held Youth B’s right
arm. While standing and walking, Staff 2 and Staff 3
escorted Youth B to an open bedroom. Youth B appeared
to move with them under his own power. Video footage
inside the bedroom was not available. Staff 2 and Staff 3
could be seen exiting the bedroom after approximately 30
seconds.
9

Documentation reviewed:
• The following facility policy & procedures were provided
and reviewed:
o “Emergency Restraint” last dated 07/18/2022
outlined policies & procedures regarding de-
escalation of youth, implementation of restraints and
the documentation and debriefing after a restraint
incident. The policy instructed that the use of
emergency restraint was consistent with Licensing
rules. It also stated that all youth placed will have
Behavioral/Calming Plans designed at the time of
admission, to be used as proactive and preventative
measures to avoid escalation.
o “Intervention Standards and Prohibitions” last dated
06/22/2022 stated that staff were prohibited from
threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment or
otherwise suggesting physical or emotional harm to
youth.
• Facility documents titled “Intensive Intervention Plan” were
provided and reviewed. This documentation individually
dated 06/23/2025, 07/30/2025, 07/10/2025 and 07/16/2025,
described the facility’s efforts to plan for and support Youth
A and any behaviors she was exhibiting. The
documentation stated that the intent was to provide Youth
A with more control over her behaviors in a more controlled
environment. Safety steps outlined by Youth A’s clinician
included locations where Youth A would be placed away
from other youth, safety precautions to limit items that
Youth A could take in her possession to be used to self-
harm or harm others, increased eyes on supervision
procedures, and non-earned interventions or privileges that
were designed specifically for Youth A. Adaptations and
additions to the plans were seen through each successive
document.
• Documentation from Youth A’s case file pertaining to
restraints was reviewed. Since her placement at the facility
on 06/16/2025 to the date of this report she had been
restrained 38 times in 62 days. In that same time frame the
facility documented only 7 restraint incidents involving other
youth placed at the facility.
• Facility Incident report documents describing incidents
involving restraints of Youth A were provided and
reviewed. Ten separate incidents were reviewed as a
sample. Youth A attempting to move past staff and escape
the area designated for her and coming into physical
10

contact with staff was a common reason for restraints to be
initiated. The documentation consistently described each
individual restraint utilized over the course of an incident.
• Facility Incident report documentation dated 06/24/2025
and authored by Staff 3 was provided and reviewed. It was
documented that Youth B had been refusing to follow any
staff directions or cease threatening other youth and staff
for roughly 45 minutes. Verbal de-escalation attempts by
staff were described. Youth B was described as
approaching staff in an aggressive manner, making
gestures that gave staff concern that he may attempt to
strike them. Youth B then continued to threaten other
youth and moved towards where other youth were
located. Youth B was then placed in a standing high hold
and escorted to a bedroom.
• Employee records were reviewed for the following staff
involved in restraints reviewed for this investigation:
o Staff 1 was originally trained in the facility restraint
models as of 09/10/2024 and had one instance of
discipline unrelated to matters of this investigation.
o Supervisor 2 was most recently trained in the facility
restraint models as of 01/27/2025 and had two
instances of discipline, one related to “standard
conduct” and one related to “conduct of
performance.”
o Supervisor 3 most recently trained in the facility
restraint models as of 05/01/2025 and had no
instances of discipline.
o Supervisor 4 most recently trained in the facility
restraint models as of 03/20/2025 and had three
instances of discipline, all unrelated to matters of this
investigation.
o Staff 2 most recently trained in the facility restraint
models as of 07/10/2025 and had one instance of
discipline unrelated to matters of this investigation.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews, video
reviewed, and documentation reviewed, the facility did not meet
licensing requirements. On multiple occasions staff initiated
restraints with youth who were not showing the severely
aggressive behavior outlined in policy and in response staff
initiated unwarranted restraints, including the restraints
documented for 06/24/2025 with Youth B and 06/25/2025,
07/01/2025 and 07/02/2025 with Youth A. These actions could
have resulted in further escalation or possible injury.
11

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• Technical assistance was offered regarding narratives used
within incident report documentation. The facility regularly
provided in depth descriptions of incidents but could
provide more clarity on the specific behaviors of concern
that led to the decision to initiate restraints.
• Technical assistance was also offered regarding the need
for proper identification of types of incidents on
documentation submitted to the department for review.
• Technical assistance was provided in the area of reasons
that a youth would be restrained. The facility is advised to
avoid initiating restraints solely because of a youth
attempting to leave a room or area if there is no immediate
risk of harm to self or others.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was provided regarding the facility’s practices to
allow for staff members to share positive attempts at rapport
building and successful prevention and de-escalation strategies
among staff. In addition, consultation was provided regarding the
provision of psychological and case file information of youth
among staff.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2025SIC0000335 approved 3/3/25; CAP approved 3/12/25
SIR #2024C0000915SI approved 12/20/23; CAP approved 1/8/24
SIR #2024C0000834SI approved 11/22/23, CAP approved 12/18/23
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
